GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express service for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUTH (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.
The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesday for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways exprekss service to Khartoum.
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for YAMBO, JEDDAH, SUAKIN MASSOWAH, HODEIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY PAPER
Established in 1880
Editor and Managder - - R. Snelling
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
FRIDAY, MARCH 22, 1907

div.head: EGYPT'S "MORAL RETROGRESSION"
div.p: Some years ago a member of the Anglican Church announced to an amazed world that Cairo was the "grave of the soul," and if our memory does not betray us gave a reasonably full account of the moral shortcomings of the population of the Capital. Whether any attempt was made to defend the reputation of the Cairene by qualified advocates, we know not, but Mr. John Robertson, M.P., has clearly taken up the mantle that has fallen from the shoulders of his predecessor and in an article entitled "The Moral Retrogression" has accused the Administration of being-indirectly of course-responsible for the increase of crime in Egypt. Mr. Robertson's thesis may be summed up as follows. While revenue has increased crime has increased, thanks to the fact that popular instruction has been neglected and that omdehs are no longer selected by the inhabitants of villages but are appointed by the Central Government. Moreover, the Government, according to Mr. Robertson, "encourages" servility among its employés, with the result that its "omdehs" deteriorate or become simply trucklers to the Administration. The whole of Mr. Robertson's thesis is based upon three assumptions : 1. That crime is absolutely on the increase ; 2 That intellectual training per se can moralise ; 3. That the Egyptians of to-day are less moral and inore servile than formerly. We have here three bold premises on which Mr. Robertson's conclu-ions depend. The first is the hardest by far to prove or disprove, for what we require is not the knowledge that more persons were imprisoned for cattle poisoning, say, in 1903 than in 1893, etc, etc., but accurate data covering long periods of years both before and after the British Occupation. Such data are unobtainable end we must therefore fall back on historical evidence.

We learn that in Lane's days crimes of violence were prevalent among the fellaheen The author of the "Modern Egyptians" states that faction fights were prevalent in the 'thirties among the villagers, who were also addicted to theft and murder, that the crimes of the "Saad" and "Yemen" parties were frequently of an atrocious nature and contrasted with the generally law-abiding behaviour of the towns people. Men went unpunished in the country for offences which would have been visited with instant decapitation by the stern Mohamed Aly, had they been committed within reach of his police and soldiers Further, we have the opinion of Sir Richard Burton--perhaps a more reliable authority on Oriental matters than Mr. John Robertson. The great Orientalist, Hadji, and traveller described the Egyptian peasantry in the 'sixties ag singularly prone to crime and deceit. It is true that he was, per contra, over inclined to emphasise the superiority of the pure Arabs and the warlike peoples of Western Asia, but his evidence cannot be dismissed as valueless. In Ismail's days crime appears to have diminished to some extent owing probably to the severity with which criminals were punished, and above all to the fact that the whole population was occupied in preserving or attempting to preserve its very existence from tax-gatherers, usurers, and inspectors of the Corvée. A people that is desperately trying to live has little opportunity for the indulgence of vicious "tendencies or for the perfection of ethical virtues. After Ismail's days crime remained stationary for a while and then increased, and we have given Mr. Robertson's explanations of this phenomenon above. They are in our opinion insufficient. We do not know, to begin with, whether Egypt is more criminal than in Mohamed Aly's days, nor do we know how far the increase lately noted may not be a purely temporary phenomenon. We know something of its causes : the wholesale annexation of a code framed for highly civilised peoples and its application to men still in a lower stage of moral development than most Europeans ; the revival of the traditions of feud and faction which had been in abeyance in Ismail's later days ; the discovery by the criminally minded that the kourbash had been abolished and that prisons were getting to resemble hotels (from the fellah point of view).

What about education ? Mr. Robertson would ask. Would it not have counteracted the other tendencies? We are doubtful, for we are not yet convinced that a community can be morally saved merely by education. It is all very well to point to noble agnostics--moral free-thinkers and the like, but what proof have we that secular education alone cap in a generation make a race exceptionally virtuous ? What we do realise is that Islam, which is the religion of an enormous majority of the Egyptians, has, owing to the neglect of its leaders, had little moralising effect on the masses. Had the Moslem leaders of Egypt been animated by the same moral zeal that fired the Indian and Russian-Tartar reformers, the moral condition of the fellabeen would be higher. A man does not necessarily become better because he is cleverer; his increased intelligence is often enough expended in baffling the policeman. But we are assured that public opinion will control him and that thanks to the growth of servility under the British Occupation such public morality is fading away ! If so why did the moral and independent public of Egypt lift no voice and raise no hand against the tyranny of Ismaili Why did no patriot among the followers of Arabi protest against the massacre of Europeans at Alexandria and the torture of Turkish officers at Cairo ? Why was Egypt allowed to go to ruin ? Servility exists in Egypt but as a legacy, a survival from a terrible and tyrannous past, and how long, we may ask, I would Ismail Pasha in his prime have borne with Mustapha Pa-ha Kamel British influence in Egypt has created the Nationalist party ; it has taught Egyptians to exercise their rights of free speech for the first time in their history, and Mr. J M. Robertson would have us believe that it has encouraged servility!

div.head: K.S.C. Gymkhana.
div.p: The K S C. Gymkhana which was)advertised for to-morrow has been postponed indefinitely

div.head: French Benevolent society.
div.p: The annual general meeting of the French Benevolent Society of Alexandria will be held at the French Consulate at 10 a m. on Sunday next.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Yesterday's plague bulletin records two cases and three deaths at Baliana, seven cages and seven deaths at Deshna, and two fatal cases at Esneh.

div.head: Sharkieh Moudirieh.
div.p: The appointment of Heddaya Bey, Chief of the Public Security, Department, as SubMoudir of the Sharkieh Province, was approved at yesterday's Council of Ministers.

div.head: The "Iona" Subscription.
div.p: Tomorrow the subscription lists opened by the French colony for the families of the Iena victims will be closed The total subscriptions up to last night were frs. 3,151.

div.head: Carduool Commemoration,
div.p: The Cairo committee of the Dante Alighieri Society will commemorate the death of Carduoci to-day at the Khedivial Opera House. Maitre Lusena Bey and Professor Trombetta will deliver speeches.

div.head: Concert
div.p: - A concert will be given at the New Khedivial Hotel on Sunday next at 9 p.m. by Mme Heincourt, assisted by several professors of music The programme includes selections for the pianoforte, harp, and violin.

div.head: The Austrian Squadron.
div.p: The Austrian Squadron has arrived at Smyrna and will remain there until the 27th inst. No official intimation has as yet been received by the Austrian Consulate at Alexandria as to the date of the squadron's arrival here.

div.head: P. O. Savings Bank.
div.p: - The deposits in the Post Office Savings Bank during the month of February amounted to LE. 44,057 and the withdrawals to L.E. 34,703, leaving a balance in hand of L E. 356,157. The number of depositors is now 62, 605.

div.head: Sleeping Cars.
div.p: Commencing from Monday, Yst April next, a sleeping car will be attached to the 11.30 p.mn. trains from Cairo to Alexandria and from Alexandria to Cairo The system of supplying rugs, etc., on hire on these trains, will be discontinued on and from the above-mentioned date.

div.head: The General Assembly.
div.p: Among the resolutions of the General Assembly (says "Al-Akhbar") there was one proposed by Kerashi Effendi Ahmed, which was not only rejected by the representatives of the nation, but immediately suppressed It was that the General Assembly should be composed in future of members who could read and write!

div.head: Treasure Trove.
div.p: A few days ago, while a fellah was making a ditch at Bernoghi, near Damanhour, he suddenly sunk into an enormous cavity. His cries attracted the neighbours, who found the man wedged between two huge subterranean walls He was dragged out and the cavity was explored. It contained numbers of funerary chambers filled with many perfectly preserved mummies

div.head: The "Train de Luxe."
div.p: Commencing from Monday, 18th April, the daily "train de luxe" running between Cairo-Luxor and vice-versa will be suppressed. Commencing from the same date, dining and sleeping cars will be attained to the night trains leaving Cairo at 8 p.m. and Luxor at 5.30 p.m., three times a week as follows: From Cairo, every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday; from Luxor, every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

div.head: Hellopolis Oasis.
div.p: The new road leading from Cairo to the Heliopolis Oasis has become the favourite promenade of tourists and residents alike. Modest promenaders, couples in search of solitude and peace, cavaliers and amazons wanting space and pure air, chauffeurs and chauffeuses, all have adopted this incomparable promenade to the oasis. At the oasis itself there is a large tent-restaurant erected in proximity to the squares of plantations and the Grand Hotel, and this has been fitted up with due regard to taste and comfort, where the many promenaders will find the best of refreshments, with hot and cold luncheons, tea, liquors, etc., all served in the best way and at moderate prices.

div.head: Notice to Advertisers
div.p: The "Egyptian Gazette" has given no advertising agency or company in Egypt any monopoly or exclusive right to act as advertising Agents on its behalf. Advertisements of every description are received at the offices of the "Gazette" from advertisers direct.

div.head:
NEW YORK SHARE MARKET
FEELING OF GENERAL BUOYANCY.
div.p: The New York market closed with about the best prices of the session. There is now a feeling of general buoyancy.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: At yesterday's Council of Ministers, besides the decision to raise the height of the Assoua Dam, already announced, the following business was transacted : -
Appointment of Mr. Williams as Inspector-General of Irrigation for Lower Egypt.
Declaration as of public utility the work of enlarging the State railway station at Shoubra; the alterations to be made to the light railway station at Belbeis, on the light railway from
Gioufa to Miniet-el-Gamh, and in the stations of Borg Nour, Choubrahour, Debig, Ekwa and Saft, and the establishment of cemeteries for Mussulmans and Copts in the village of Kom Ombo.
Convocation of the provincial councils of the Kalioubieh and Sharkieh Moudiriehs for the 30th March and 6th April.

div.head: CAIRO ESTATES COMPANY.
div.p: The Khedivial decree authorising the forma. tion of the Cairo Estates Company has been signed and the prospectus of this company will appear in our issue of Monday.

This is a filial company of the Egyptian Estates, Limited, and its object is to develop the great amount of new business which the parent company is unable to cope with, and which is somewhat outside the scope of the objects which the Egyptian Estates was origin. ally intended to deal with. It is an Egyptian company with a capital of LE 400 000 in 100,000 shares of L E. 4 rach. There will be no founders' or preference shares. The board of directors is a very strong one and is composed as follows : Messrs. Greville H. Palmer, of the Bank of Egypt, and Chairman of the Egyptian Estates, Montague Summers, managing director of the Egyptian Estates, George Nungovich, local director, Egyptian Estates, Alfred Curphey, director of the Cairo Suburban Building Lands Company, and Multre Carton de Wiart. Only 50,000 shares will be offered to the public and the shareholders of the Egyptian Estates will have a preferential right to the shares. The capital has been subscribed as follows: Egyptian Estates, Limited, 50,000; Mr. Montagu Summers, 15,000; Mr. Greville Palmer, 5,000 ; George Nungovich Bey, 10,000; M. François Rom, 5,000 ; Mr. L. Carton de Wiart, 6,000; M, P. Barnard, 5,000 ; Mr. E.C. Hogg, 5,000.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES, LIMITED.
div.p: We learn that the Egyptian Estates, Limited, have sold 22,000 pics of land on the Mahmoudieh Canal at a price which represents a profit to the company of 50 per cent. -

div.head: BANQUE DU CURE, LIMITED.
div.p: The applications for shares in this new bank have surpassed the expectations of the founders and have been so numerous that they exceed considerably the number offered for public subscription. The result is considered the more satisfactory when the present stringency in the money ma ket is taken into account.
The alterations in the premises in the Sharia Boulac are rapidly approaching completion and the bank will open for business in the first or second week of April.

div.head: SUDAN LANDS AND COMMERCIAL COMPANY.
div.p: The dec ne authorising the formation of this company has been signed. The public issue will take place in the course of next month.

div.head: UNITED HOTELS OF EGYPT, LTD.
div.p: This company has gone to allotment. The capital was all underwritten beforehand and fully guaranteed.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LIGNOLITE AND BRICK COMPANY, LIMITED
div.p: This company, whose capital is £50,000, fully subscribed, is offering 16,500 shares of £ì each to public subscription. The issue will be open on Tuesday, 26th inst., and will close on the following day.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LAND INVESTMENT AND BUILDING CO.
div.p: A few weeks back the above company bought from the Princess Enissa, wife of Prince Mohamed Aly Halim, her property of 104 feddang situated at Rod-el-Farag, in cl 90 proximity to the new tramway which is being laid from the Shoubra Caracol to the Ismailieh Canal, as well as the contemplated extension which the Tramway Company will build later to Embabeh Bridge We understand that the company has already received two or three offers for the purchase of the land. The last offer, if accepted, would leave a net profit of £72,000. This, it seems, is the reason for the recent appreciation in the price of the founders' shares.

div.head:
THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY
RESOLUTIONS DEPRECATED.
div.p: The resolutions of the Egyptian General Assembly have not only been deprecated by the British Chamber of Commerce but the leading European merchants of Alexandria, without any distinction of nationality, have joined in protesting against the movement in favour of handing over the control of the finances of the country to an Egyptian Parliament.

The members of such important international institutions as the Alexandria General Produce Association and the Alexandria Import Association (Association du Commerce d Importation) have signified their approval of the action of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt in gending a letter of protest to Lord Cromer and of passing a resolution against any material change in the existing system of Administration. Both these influential mercantile corporations, which represent the most important trade interests of Egypt's commercial capital, have forwarded their protests against the policy of the General Assembly direct to Lord Cromer Their example is being followed by other Chambers of Commerce at Alexandria. In fact, the European capitalists of Alexandria are practically unanimous in holding that any material change in the present system of Government would be fatal to the best interests of all classes in Egypt, both native and European, and would do grievous harm to the moral and financial prosperity of the country.
An address has been signed by the business men of Cairo, irrespective of nationality, strongly protesting against any change in the existing system of administration.
The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs has received the resolution of the British Chamber of Commerce, which was passed at the meeting held on the 7th inst.

div.head: THE GRANDMOULIN AFFAIR.
div.p: It is stated that M. Grandmoulin intends claiming damages to the extent of L.E 5,000 from the newspapers which have libelled him.

The Parquet will question the Omdeh of Warrak on the matter, as Mustapha Pasha Kamel has declared that he only gave the facts of the case in accordance with the information contained in the let er from the omdeh.

We regret to see that our contemporary the "Egyptian Standard" fails to explain away the atrocious charge which it recently brought against M Grandmoulin. The English organ of Mustapha Pasha Kamel recently asked, as we noted in our leading article of Tuesday last : "How is it possible that M. Grandmoulin still keeps his Government employ accused and guilty as he is of assassination?

The "Egyptian Standard" in reply says : "The sentence which the "Egyptian Gazette" has the kindness to draw our attention to is at its very worst but ambiguous. In itself it implies no accusation on our part nor a prejudgment. When its context is compared with all our other statements in the same paragraph (and which the "Egyptian Gazette" took care not to print in italics) it is self-evident that no doubt whatever could cling to our meaning in writing those words, namely that M. Grandmoulin had been accused of something he had done. Because, the moinent the shot went off while the gun was in M. Grandmoulin's hands, and killed a boy, it is certain that before the law M. Grandmoulin was not innocent of a charge brought against him. As to its being a wilful or an involuntary act we expressed no opinion whatsoever in any one of our organs. The word employed by us to designate the act accident which had taken place, was simply and solely one of three at our disposal."

Nobody can consider that the above futile explanation in the slightest degree clears or contemporary. The point is not what the writer meant by his statement, but what would his readers understand him to mean, and there unfortunately can be no question about the meaning of the phrase guilty as he is of assassination.

div.head: A MOUSKY TRAGEDY.
div.p: A Greek carpenter for two years past had been living with a Greek girl of the name of Mirka Souloyanni in the Mousky quarter of Cairo. A few days ago a cousin of the woman arrived in Cairo and was invited to spend last Sunday at their residence. The guest had only just sat down at table when he suddenly asked his hoste if they were married. They replied in the negative but added they would get married as soon as they had the money. Their guest, whose name is Gheorghi Souloyanni, thereupon rose from the table and declared that he would never go back to their house until they were married. He, however, returned on Tuesday and, finding his cousin alone, plunged a knife into her three times. The assassin, who is a Greek subject, has been incarcerated in the Mousky Caracol

Yesterday he was brought before the Chief of the Parquet and avowed his crime with cynical self-control The original motive which he gave for the murder, namely, that he did it to preserve the honour of his family, has not been received with much faith by the judicial authorities, who believe that there may be other and more sinister motives. The unfortunate woman died without recovering consciousness. She leaves a little girl,

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Cunard S.S. Pavis is due here on 26th inst., and will immediately begin loading cargo I for Liverpool and American porte,

div.head: MILITARY TOURNAMENT
E.A. Offices "AT HOME"
div.p: Yesterday's Military Tournament was a thorough success, and the officers of the Egyptian Army gave their friends a very pleasant and enjoyable afternoon. The weather was excellent, the audience enthusiastic, and the er ents keenly and well contested. The tent pegging was better done than in previous years, some of the squads and individuals—distinguishing themselves greatly; while the displays of physical drill, gymnastics, sword v. bayonet, and bayonet v lance, etc, were all worth watching. The wrestling on horseback supplied an unusual feature, a horse getting rid of its nose bag and seizing a trooper by the forearm. As far as one could see, however, the cavalryman was little the worse for this unrehearsed effect in the display

H.H. the Khedive arrived shortly before 4 p.in. and was received by the Sirdar, to whom he expressed his great pleasure at the high standard maintained in the various events. An excellent tea was provided for the many gitests and a well chosen selection of music played by the Egyptian Army band was greatly appreciated.

div.head: CANAL AGAIN CLEAR (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT )
div.p: The Dutch steamer Rindjani was refloated this forenoon, with the assistance of the tug Titan, when the Canal was again clear to traffic after a stoppage of about 24 hours
The homeward-bound steamers were kept moored in order to let the outward-bound pass, and thus the S.S. China, carrying the Indian mail, came out of the Canal at 1.40 this afternoon and proceeded.

div.head: SCOTCH CHURCH FOR CAIRO.
div.p: Many members of the Scottish community in Egypt will be glad to learn that there is now a definite prospect of a permanent church being erected in Cairo in connection with the Church of Scotland. A convenient site has been found, and a number of handsome subscriptions have recently been promised, there being also a prospect of substantial assistance from the Colonial Committee of the church In these circumstances the committee of management of St. Andrew's Church in Cairo has arranged to cell a meeting of the congregation and all others interested in the movement, for the purpose of appointing a large and representative committee, including the members of the existing committee, to take steps to carry out the proposal, which has been long entertained, for the erection of a church. The meeting will be hold on Monday, the 25th inst., at half-past five o'clock, in the present place of worship, off Kasr el-Nil-street, beside the British Headquarters.

div.head: GERMAN CHURCH.
div.p: This morning at 10 o'clock the foundation stone of the new German Church at Boulac was laid. Dr. Dregender, the Kaiser's private chaplain, pronounced the blessing and made a speech, as did also Baron von Gruenau, the arting German Diplomatic Agent. The members of the colony afterwards lunched at the Grand Continental Hotel This evening there will be a fête at the German Club. On Saturday Dr. Dregender will conduct a service at the old church in the Ismailieh quarter.

div.head: DISCOVERIES AT ASSOUAN.
div.p: The Clermont-Ganneau Mission has made some remarkable archæological discoveries at A 380an. Two fine statues in diorite, of the time of Thothmes III., have been found. They are covered with inscriptions, which are said to be very interesting from an historical and a religious point of view. The statues have been purposely decapitated and the mission are now Looking for the heads The bodies are in an excellent state of preservation.

A number of Aramean Jewish ostrakas are also being brought to light almost daily One of the Aramean settlements at Elephantine has just been discovered after a long search. Baron Edm nd de Rothschild, when at Assouan recently, was. 80 interested in the work of the mission that he gave M. Clermont-Ganneau 10,000 france to continue his excavations.

div.head: A RARE-MOSQUE LAMP
div.p: - Mr. Blanchard, the well known dealer in antiquities, who lately sold a very fine mosque lump to the Arab Museum, has been fortunate enough to obtain from the same collection another lamp to which considerable historical interest attaches. It belonged formerly to the Duc de Nemours, son of Louis Phillipe who obtained it on the taking of Algiers, when Abd-el-Kader surrendered to the French The Limp found its way by various stages into the Hands of an English nobleman, who took it with him to London and afterwards disposed of it and it has now passed into the hands of Mr. Blanchard.
The lamp itself is of blue glass covered with lu design in enamel and is an extremely handsome object. It is to be hoped that such an interesting lamp will remain in the country.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria) half way to San Stefano

div.head: ABBAS THEATRE
THE ITALIAN OPERA SEASON.
div.p: Italian Opera in Cairo came to an end last week. It is with mixed feelings that one must summarize the performances, some of which were admirable and some deplorable. The first performance of P ccini's "Bohème" was about the best piece of work I ever saw in Cairo, there were really great moments in "Mefisto fele," "aida" was excellent, and the march therein remarkable. "Fedora" was good, as weg "Tosca," very good in parts, and there were pleasing moments in most of the pieces. "Carmeu" I committed, that was quite excellent But we must set against this many disappointments ; and as these were due to arrangements and singers we may as well cite names. Signora Isaia rather spoilt "Faust." She is a type of what the Italian soprano can be, too florid and with excessive and wearisome vibrato. Signora Fabris, though conscientious and accurates, has often deplorably thin, reedy, high notes. Her lower and middle notes are charming, but the rest are trying Signor Tschierdo went completely to pieces through overwork ; and Signor Battani--it was pathetic when one remembered the exquisite voice we had heard in the summer of 1906, and contrasted it with what he now is : harsh and cracked, singing with manifest effort. Except for a note now and again all the beauty had left his voice-- again overwork and the evil climate are to blame. Signor Valls, who has a really fine voice, only appeared once or twice. Signor Lucenti was the mainstay and real delight of the whole company. His reading of Mefistofele is remarkable. One can hardly see how it could be surpassed As Ramfis, as Mefistofeles in "Faust," as Alviso in "Gioconda," in his one appearance in "Bohème," wherever he appeared, he was splendid He is one of the three or four best, if not the best singer we have had in Egypt this season. Signori Arrighetti and Pompa have both improved to a great extent. Their voices are full and true and pleasing in tone. Signora Orbellini was charming as Tosca and very good in almost all she did, and Signora Fassini was delightful. Her voice has great depth and fullness, and yet" is soft and sympathetic. Her dance in "Carmen" was purely fascinating Signora Mastropasqua always looked attractive, and sang prettily though her voice is rather light for such parts as Gilda. The rest were fair at times, but not always very sympathetic or tuneful. Signora Garagnani is better than most "utility" sopranos. She has plenty of voice, rather hard at times, but always true, and her acting is quite good. Of the chorus, the male voices were decent enough, the rest.very poor; when under Signor Campanini's eye! they sang well ; but the singing behind the scenes usually resulted in collapse. The orchestra are fair as musicians, but careless. They do not always time their instruments well ; and to this the conductor ought to have seen. Signor Ricci was hardly forcible enough for them ; he was too painstaking and pei haps even-tempered. Signor Campanini was very different to him and to inost conductors we have had here. He was remarkable at times, and transformed orchestra, chorus, and singers; he seemed to be able to do anything with them. To watch his baton and his hands alone was the keenest pleasure. He and Lucenti between them did not merely save Mefistofele : they made it memorable. His reading of the 3rd act of "Tosca," or "Aida," of some parts of "Faust" was unusually a mirable : he is the son of the famous Campanini and if he continues and enhances the promise he gives now, he should be famous himself. The one important omission was the "Huguenots"--a great, pity as Valls and Lucenti would both have sung in it. On the whole the fine performances amply made up for the failures, and were a real relief and contrast to the trying and uneven efforts of the Khedivial Theatre. If the management had only secured another and a really good soprano, and had not overworked their light tenors, and-more especially--had selected a good chorus of sopranos and altos, the whole programme might have been as brilliant a success as were its best iteins. The receipts should have been good enough to warrant this, as there were often crowded houses. We must hope for their reappearance and that they will have introduced some such improvements. Signor Lucenti is, it seems, coming here next year. Let us trust the rest will be worthy of him.

div.head: MENA HOUSE.
div.p: We understand that Mena House Hotel, which has had the best season on record, will remain open until the 1st May at least. It has been decided, in consequence of the numerous applications for accommodation that the Management has had to refuse during the winter, to considerably enlarge the hotel by the addition of another wing of 100 rooms,
which, will be built during the coming summer - months and be ready for the commencement
of next season, when it has been likewise decided to run a service of small motor 'buses,
to accommodate about 10 persons. between - Mena House and the city, starting in the latter - case from the Cairo railway station.

div.head: CAIRO BILLIARD TOURNAMENT
FINAL ROUND.
div.p: Despite the fact that the markers' billiard tournament had already been won by Percy by his two victories at Shepheard's and one at Ghezireh Palace, the interest shown in the final round, which was played at the Grand Continental Hotel on Wednesday night, Syer being "at home" to Percy and Flowers, was keeper t' an ever, for Syer's many supporters looked forward to him taking ample revenge for his defeats by his two opponents on their own tables.

On this occasion the billiard saloon of the Continental was excellently filled, and at 9.80 p.m. Syer and Percy commenced their match. Almost immediately after the opening Syer got ahead of his opponent, to whom, it must be remembered, he coucerled 50, by steady play and a very pretty break of 34, and though Percy at times looked like drawing level with him, he kept a good lead throughout. In the course of the game Syer gave several pretty exhibitions, including breaks of 23, 28, 21 (all off the red), 26, and ran out with a splendid 43 unfinished, which he continued in response to the general demand, and only broke down very unluckily at 84. Percy's play was steady throughout and showed much thoroughness, while his principal breaks were 28, 21, and 28. The game lasted an hour and ten minutes, the final score being Syer, 800 ; Percy (received 50), 226.

After the customary collection had been made for the benefit of the hotel markers by Mr Bernie Mansfield (and, we are glad to note, with more handsome results than ever) Syer and Flowers commenced the final match, by Flowers playing a safety miss into baulk. Two more safety misses followed and Syer then made a good break of 26 from a pretty cannou off the red off three cushions. This he speedily followed with a very neatly compiled 50, and he good overtook his opponent, who had received a start of 75. Though doing nothing brilliant, however, Flowers kept on playing some very neat shots and by a series of small breaks kept within measurable distance of Syer The latter broke down rather badly once or twice, but, besides the breaks already mentioned, he put together 24, 28, 35, and 28 and gained the victory by 58, the final scores being 300-242. Play in this game lasted 55 minutes.
The games of the tournament have resulted as follows:-
Percy (Shepheard's), ... winner 3.
Syer (Continental) ... ... ... 2.
Flowers (Ghezireh Palace) ... 1.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lady Cromer will not be "At Home" tomorrow as her ladyship has been summoned to see H.H. the Khedivah at Koubbeh.

Viscountess Parker and Captain Matthews have left for Egypt, and will not return to London until the end of April. Viscountess Parker was the second wife of the late Viscount and their only son is the present Earl of Macclesfield. She married Captain L. W. Matthews in 1897 and retains her title by courtesy.
El-Lewa Sir R. Baron von Slatin Pagha, Inspector General of the Soudan, left Khartoum last week for Merwi on a tour of inspection in the Dongola Province,

Colonel Cuthbert Larking, who served as JA D C, to the late Khedive and who holds the rank of Bey, has been seriously ill. His wife, Lady Adela Larking, who for many years held the office of Lady-in-waiting to the Duchess of Connaught, is a sister of the present Earl of Listowel and Victoria, Countess of Yarborough. Another sister is Lady Sophia Macnamara, Lady-in-waiting to Princess Louise, Duchess of Argyll.
Mr. Michel Theotokis, brother of the Hel. lenic Prime Minister, is staying at Schutz, Ramleh, with Mr. Costa Garifallo.

Mr. Nicholas Leonidas, formerly President of the Hellenic Chamber of Deputies, is due to arrive at Alexandria from Athens to-day. As already announced, the object of his visit to Egypt is to start a new line of steamers between Alexandria and the Greek and Levantine ports.

We see from the latest London papers that Dr. F. M. Sandwith, who retired from practica in Cairo a year ago, has now been elected Gresham Lecturer on Medicine. The appointment is made by the Mercers' Company of the City of London, and the lectures are delivered twelve timog a-year under their auspices.

Major B. C. M. Carter, who has spent seven years with the Egyptian Army, hag been attached to the 2nd Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers, which he first joined sixteen yean ago, and with which he served in the Khartoum campaign, 1898. In the same year he was given a company in the Srd Battalion, raised at Preston and just disbanded under Mr. Haldane's scbemo.
The passengers by the train de luxo for Upper Egypt on Wednesday night were : Mr. Duburgart, Mr. and Mro. Zitch, Prof. Yanarik, Mr. Barnea, Mr. James and party, Dr. Chris tofaraon

div.head:
IMPERIAL PARLIAMENT.
A RECORD SITTING. GOVERNMENT AND CHANNEL TUNNEL

div.p: House of COMMONS.—The House adjourned it 5,37 o'clock, after a 27 hours sitting, which constitutes a record since the time of Parnell, l'he cause was the Opposition's resentment at be alleged breach of faith regarding the procedure.

Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman announced that be Government would oppose the Channel Tunnel Bill. A feeling of insecurity would constantly lead to unnecessary naval and military expenditure. Mr. Balfour was gratified at the announcement.
(Reuter)

Lord Selborne, in his speech at the opening of Parliament, said that the employment of Chinese would cease at the earliest possible moment, but that no steps would be taken to repatriate them unless an effective substitute n the form of other labour or improved meChanical appliances were found. 7

The Ministers will give the mining industry every assistance. He earnestly prayed that the country may enjoy permanent peace and progress. All matters of contention will be postponed for consideration till June as it is urgently necessary to deal with the Asiatic question, in which compulsory registration is che essential fore-runner.
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE DUMA.
GOVERNMENT MEASURES OF REFORM.

div.p: The Government will submit to the Duma 79 measures of reform, but the discussions so far have been devoted to attacks on the administration with regard to the famine question.
(Reuter)
The Duma has adopted a proposition calling for immediate measures for the assistance of the population of the provinces where famine prevails.
(Hlavas)

div.head:
DISORDERS IN ROMANIA.
JEWS FLEEING WHOLESALE.

div.p: The Jews are fleeing wholesale to Austria. The epimosity of the peasants is chiefly directed against the extortionate Jewish landowners. Innocent and guilty Jews are suffering alike.
(Reuter)
The agrarian disorders continue in the north of Rumania. It is rumoured that 30,000 peasants surround the town of Jassy. (Hadas)

div.head:
CORRUPTION IN 'FRISCO.
OFFICIALS HEAVILY BRIBED. CORRUPTION IN 'FRISCO.

div.p: All the members of the Board of Supervision which governs the city have confessed to hay. ing received enormous bribes for favouring certain enterprises, while Mayor Schmitz himself received about £60,000. His trial will shortly take place,
(Reuter)

div.head:
HAMBURG DOCK STRIKE.
234 VESSELS LYING IDLE.

div.p: The dockers' strike is protracted and 234 vessels are now lying idle. Freight is accumu. lating. English dockers were recruited but 167 of them refused to work. Others are being engaged in London.
(Reuter)
Liverpool Spring Cup. 1. Bride of Candy ; 2. Wild Aster ; 3. Cadwal. -
(Reuter)

div.head: BRITISH CONTROL OF EGYPT.
THE MORAL RETROGRESSION.
div.p: By John M. ROBERTSON, M.P. That moral life is going back in Egypt, while the material life is going forward, lies on the face of the official reports. Year after year it is announced that the increase in revenue is accompanied by an increase of crime ; and in Lord Cromer's Report for 1905 there is communicated the opinion of Captain Machell, the British " Adviser " to the Ministry of the In. terior, that the increase of crime is the direct result of the advancing prosperity Thus the British administration in Egypt is in the piquant position of demanding gratitude from the Egyptian people for having increased the national income, while affirming that that very increase is the cause of national demoralisation.

I do not for a moment gay that Captain Machell's theory of the causation of crime is sound. I met only one man in Egypt in e month who subscribed to it; and the British officials are as little satisfied with it as the Egyptians. In no other country, I fancy, has such a theory ever been put forward. But it holds the ground as the official theory for the time being ; and it entitles every Egyptian Nationalist to say : " So be it : if the prosperity you claim to have caused be the source of our moral retrogression, you had better clear out and let us revert to honest poverty. And you will be good enough, in the circumstances, to dispense with our gratitude." Were a father to say to his son : " I have given you a large income and enabled you to live in luxury : it.. is your own fault if, living in tutelage, you have grown vicious," he would not generally be held to have a strong case.
SERVILITY - ENCOURAGED.

What the British Control has done for Egypt, on the side of the moral and intellectual life, is to upset and deracinate the old social and political organisation without substituting any. thing equally efficient and, above all, without giving any such popular instruction as shall | put the people upon the way of healthy self government on new lines. In the old days, the omdeh or headman of every village was chosen by the people ; and under that system crime

was checked by the feudal or quasi-patriarchal power with which he was invested. By the admission of Captain Machell, the British Control during a number of years pursued the policy of disregarding the feudal spirit of the people, with bad results. The excuse was that the feudal method involved feuds; and the idea was to appoint men of less weight on the score that they did not represent a faction. To this it should be added that the constant tendency of the British Administration, despite the bias of its best men, is to insist upon and develop servility in all natives to whom it gives appointments; and that every sign of self respect and independence on the part of village headmen or mudirs (governors of provinces) is officially represented --if not by the chief authorities then by the majority of the inspectors,

The outcome is that while we in Britain boast of our racial conservatism as having made us wisely slow to upset old usages -- in contrast with the rash French, who so readily "break with the past"—in Egypt, as elsewhere, we have played skittles with the oldest institutions and the most important social relations. What we consider risky for ourselves we force upon less advanced communities without scruple, though in their case all sudden and sweeping change is obviously more hazardous. The result is a noticeable increase of criminality in certain provinces. The crimes on the increase are mainly those of personal malice and retaliation ; and one of the causes would certainly appear to be the lowering of the status of omdehs by the method of selection latterly pursued. Where the headman is seen to be of no account, primitive crime grows bold There are, of course, other cases. In some districts the reclamation of land involves 1 the expulsion of Bedouin "squatters, who revenge themselves as best they can. It is certain that really good inspectors--men with a gift of conciliation can do, and have done, much to end old feuds. But the official figures tell of a general or frequent failure to cope with the evil ; and there is no prospect whatever of an improvement.
It is admitted that even now a really capable o ndeh can keep his village nearly free of |irimo The Administration protest that their difficulty is precisely that of finding good men.

The answer is that their attitude towards independent men loges thom thg service of many of the best that their arbitrary methods of appointment can succeed only by accident ; and that finally, they will not take the right way to increase the number of instructed and competent men in Egypt.
EDUCATIONAL NEEDS.

To raise the levels of social life, two things are required -- the better instruction of all classes of natives, and the enlistment of all classes to some extent in the cause of better government. Ia neither of these directions does the Administration make any general advance. Something is done for education in the way of providing new kuttabs, or elementary schools (mostly built by native notables), and in the development of primary and secondary Government schools. One entirely hopeful feature is the creation of schools for girls, and the beginning of a system of training native female teachers for these. Should this movement continue, wonders may be worked. But there is needed a great national system of popular education to overtake the enormous mass of illiteracy, and an enlightened system of higher education, and neither is forthcoming.

A spontaneous native movement to establish a modern university has been promptly and sedulously discouraged by the Administration on the score that it is "premature," when in reality the sole justification of such a plea is that the British Control has arrested the supply of young natives qualified to make the best use of such a university. Meantime, nothing is proposed that will tend to restore the class in question, which existed under the old regime, and indeed down till the beginning of the present century.

One of the grounds on which popular education has been restricted in the past is the danger of taking too many youths away from agriculture and setting them to swell injuriously the ranks of the clerk class. The same drawback faces educationists at home. But to fall back on a policy of inaction is no solution, The way to prevent elementary education from multiplying harmfully the competitors for clerkships is to make it so general that it is no special qualification ?

The answer is that their attitude towards independent men loges thom thg service of many of the best that their arbitrary methods of appointment can succeed only by accident ; and that finally, they will not take the right way to increase the number of instructed and competent men in Egypt.
EDUCATIONAL NEEDS.

To raise the levels of social life, two things are required -- the better instruction of all classes of natives, and the enlistment of all classes to some extent in the cause of better government. Ia neither of these directions does the Administration make any general advance. Something is done for education in the way of providing new kuttabs, or elementary schools (mostly built by native notables), and in the development of primary and secondary Government schools. One entirely hopeful feature is the creation of schools for girls, and the beginning of a system of training native female teachers for these. Should this movement continue, wonders may be worked. But there is needed a great national system of popular education to overtake the enormous mass of illiteracy, and an enlightened system of higher education, and neither is forthcoming.

A spontaneous native movement to establish a modern university has been promptly and sedulously discouraged by the Administration on the score that it is "premature," when in reality the sole justification of such a plea is that the British Control has arrested the supply of young natives qualified to make the best use of such a university. Meantime, nothing is proposed that will tend to restore the class in question, which existed under the old regime, and indeed down till the beginning of the present century.

One of the grounds on which popular education has been restricted in the past is the danger of taking too many youths away from agriculture and setting them to swell injuriously the ranks of the clerk class. The same drawback faces educationists at home. But to fall back on a policy of inaction is no solution, The way to prevent elementary education from multiplying harmfully the competitors for clerkships is to make it so general that it is no special qualification.

div.head: EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM,
div.p: Mr. Edward Dicey has published an article in the "Daily Telegraph" in which he ridicules Mr. J M. Robertson's efforts and calls him a well meaning doctrinaire. He shows that the less Parliament takes up the Egyptian Question the better for all concerned Mr. Dicey attacks Mustapha Kamel Pasha,charging him with wishing to restore Turkish supremacy in Egypt. " The Egyptian Standard," continues Mr. Dicey, will prove a dead failure.
The Egyptian Standard" comments on Mr. Dicey's article under the heading "Mr Dicey's Relapse," as though he were guilty of apostasy. Mustapha Pasha Kamel's organ remarks :-

It is (we think) almost equivalent to his repentance for having written some of the most able chapters in his book on "The Egypt of the Future"-it can carry but little weight. Had his opinions concerning our Director's desires to restore Turkish supremacy been written a month ago when "Al Lewa" was the only National organ and could not deny in broad English false accusations brought against it, some importance might have been attached to Mr. Dicey's statements. But to-day 1. They are behind the times and unimportant The National party is simply and solely fighting for the liberty, the self government in Egypt, the keeping of those promises made by England and which have not been kept.It wishes Egypt to be the free friend of Europe and not the oppressed vassal slave. Does that signify that it is the National Party's desire to restore Turkish supremacy ? It does signify that the National Party's aim is to restore to Egypt, Funder a constitutional form, her old liberty, existing prior to the coming of the English and French. As regards the financial control of Egypt as long as she is in debt to Europe. Our Director accepted an international control in a previous issue of the " Egyptian Standard," so that this matter would not create a scare among fearing stock-brokers, capitalists and bond-holders.

div.head: HELIOPOLIS OSIS
CREATING A TOWN.
div.p: The following is the conclusion of Mr. Dicey's article in the "Daily Telegraph," the first part of which was published in our issue of yesterday :--

There upon negotiations were entered into between the Khedivial Government, which owns all unoccupied desert land in Egypt, and MM. Boghos Pa-ha Nubar and Empain, which resulted in the following arrangement : The Government agreed to cede the promoters of the Oasis City scheme. 6,000 acres of desert land, distant about five miles east of Cairo, adjoining the track of the old Cairo to Suez Railway, which had been abandoned aş uşeleg after the completion of the Suez canal. The land thus ceded was given for an almost normal price, subject to the conditions that the city should be erected in a block of 1,000 acres, while the remaining 5,000 were never to be built upon, so as to gecure for perpetuity an open space between the old and the new Cairo. There was no dispute as to the site of the Oasis City. The desert of Suez does not border any. where on the Nile, and the ground riser gradually from the baņks of the river till it reaches the crest of a row of sandhills, which look to me as if they were spurs of the Mokattam Range, over-hanging the citadel of Cairo. The time had now arrived to settle the plans and dimensions of the Oasis City. It was then that M. Empain's marvellous genius as an organiser of great enterprises came into play.

My impression, from what I have heard, is that at the outset the idea had been to build a certain limited number of houses at Oasis City. and to ascertain whether there was sufficient demand for such dwellings at so great a distance from the business quarters and the public offices of Cairo. M. Empain, however, contended that an experiment of this kind would be insufficient, that the construction of a number of specimen villas would require a stafi of engineers, architects, builders, experts in irrigation, roadmakers, and railway constructors of almost equal numbers to those required to construct the whole city ; that in the long run the outlay would be infinitely less onerous if the new city was constructed in parts, instead of as one big job; and that tenants would not be found to take houses in a barren desert till they were provided with waterworks, roads, tramways, and electric railways, and all the "amenities," to use a Scotch phrase, of a civilised city. The force of M. Empain's arguments, and I suspect even more the extraordinary vigour of his individuality, carried the day ; his fellow-promoters not only followed his advice, but threw themselves heart and soul into his project. In the early part of last year the prospectus of the Oasis City Company was issued in Egypt, and the demand for shares was 90 great that before the application list was closed the £1 shares bad risen to a premium of between $3 and £4, at which figure they still stand.

The causes of this unwonted demand were of various character. The first was the composition of the board, which, unlike most of the companies placed on the Egyptian market, was, with very few exceptions, composed of men who, whether English, Belgian, or Egyptian, were all known and respected in Egypt both by natives and foreigners. Then the fact of Boghos Pasha having been the originator of the Oasis City project told strongly with the Egyptian public on account not only of his name and wealth, but of the high character he holds as a man of sound judgment, great commonsense, a large and successful landowner, and the last person likely to risk his own fortune and that of his friends in any speculative enterprise of whose success he was not well assured. Moreover, it was manifest that if men of such great experience as his Excellency Boghos Pasha Nubar, M. Empain, and M Carton de Wiart, the leading advocate of the Egyptian Bar, had associated their names with the construction of a new suburb of Cairo in the desert of Suez, it followed that in their judgment the present demand for building sites and for residential houses within Cairo proper was likely to remain substantially on its present scale for many years to come. This indirect testimony to the probable continuance of the boom was naturally very acceptable to the promoters of the various 'companies with which the Cairene and Alexandrian markets have been flooded during the last two years, and this may have accounted for the extraordinary number of applications for shares and to the high premium the shares reached on allotment. GOOD ROADS AND EXPRESS TRAMS.

In order to realise the greatness of the task taken in hand by the syndicate who underwrote the Oasis City Company, it is necessary to appreciate the initial difficulties with which they had to contend They had not only to construct a township of comfortable houses and Aats, covering an area of 1,000 acres, and to find tenants at a moderate rental, but they had to provide cheap and rapid modes of transit between Cairo and its new suburb, to supply each tenement with gardens, water, and electricity, to place them apart at a distance which would secure a current of fresh air, and to do all this in conformity with the somewhat arbitrary regulations imposed upon them by the Egyptian Góvernment and the British authorities. What they have already accomplished is absolutely marvellous. If you visit the embryo city of the desert and use your eyes you need no imagination to judge for yourself what the new Cairo of the s burbs will look like when finally completed. Good, hard, macadamised roads have been constructed in every direction, over which you can walk, or Hide, or drive, cither by ourriaga or motor, as rapidly and as smoothly as you can along the highways of England of France; there is in course of construction a network of electric tramways, 80 contrived as to communicate with the Cairo Electrio Tramcar Company, of which M. Empain is, I believe, the chairman, and by which any passenger can travel from the Oasis City to any part of Cairo without change of carriages

There is to be a direct tramline worked by electricity, which is to convey passengers from the Oasis city to the Cairo terminus in under ten minutes. An enormous hotel is being built. The first three of its four storeys, which will contain 300 bed-rooms, have been already completed, and will be open by the commencement of next season. A very considerable number of plots in the Oasis City have already been applied for, and most of these plots are now being comtr icted by the company. The spectacle of the roads, railroads, tramways, buildings, houses, offices, now in course of construction, when I revisited the spot during the present week, recalled to my mind one of the sights in which I have always taken the strongest interest, that of an ant hill being built up or repaired by a swarm of ante. Looking down from the brow of the band ridge, on which the Oasis City is to stand, the 8,000 labourers, mostly fellaheen, seemed to me, as seen from a distance, like a multitude of insects struggling blindly in every direction, and yet, as you watched them carefully from afar, bringing order out of chaos and working together with a common purpose to bring about a common end.
AN EASTERN PICTURE.

I confess, however that my attention was more or legs attracted from the progress of the builders and workers by the unexpected beauty of the view, as seen from the ridge, which is to form the foreground, if I may use the woods of the Oasis City. I have always, ever since I first visited Cairo, thought the view of the Nile Valley, as seen from the citadel, to be one of the niost beautiful I have ever witnessed in any country of the world. I confess, however, the view of Cairo and of the Pyramids and of the Delta as seen from the Suez desert surrounding the Oasis City, rivals in my estimation the view from the citadel. It so happened that I was there when the sun was sinking in the west, and Cairo, Ghezireh, and the Pyramids themselves were all lighted up by one of those gorgeous masses of shifting colour which are only to be witnessed in the East. Somehow it added, to my thinking, to the Oriental character of the scene, on which gazed, to notice that as the hour of prayer approached with the setting sun, workman after workman dropped out of the serried ranks labouring at the foot of the ridge on which I stood, knelt down, bowed his head to the ground, and repeated the prayer of Islam, that there is one God, and that Mahomet is his prophet

I am not an optimist by disposition, and, even if I had any reason for expressing an opinion as to the financial prospects of the Dasis City, I should distrist the value of my own opinion. This much, however, I can fairly say, that the air of the desert suburb is infinitely dryer and fresher than that of Cairo itself, or of Ghezireh. I cannot but think that visitors who come to Egypt to avoid cold and Wet and fog will do wisely if they take up their abode in the Oasis City socmer than remain in Jiiro, especially if it is to be pulled to pieces in order to inaugurate a system of water drainage Moreover, I am certain that in one respect at any rate Cairo will have reason to be thankful to the founders of the Oasis City for having removed one of the great defects of the capital of Egypt from a foreigner's point of view ; that is, the almost total absence of roads. Practically there is only one drive in Cairo, and that is the road to and from the Pyramids, a distance of about nine kilometres, a road most monotonous in itself, and mainly occupied by tramways.

The Oasis Company has already constructed an excellent carriage-road, passing from the Matarieh Railway terminus in Cairo, by Zeitoun, Koubbeh, the Khedive's Palace, the Virgin's Tree, and so on to Oasis City, and returning thence to Cairo by the Abbassi-h suburb, a distance of sixteen kilometres. The roads are Bo well constructed that they may be expected to remain in use for many a year to come.

div.head: M. KOEHLER'S RECITAL.
div.p: M. Heinrich Koehler gave a piano concert at the Savoy Hotel on Tuesday afternoon He played some interesting music and showed considerable technique and knowledge, but his interpretation is almost too conscientious to be pleasing : he is too matter of fact and even monotonous at times. The opening piece by Hummel and the Chopin Nocturne especially showed this He minimised the perfect effect of flow in the latter and did not emphasize the rhythm sufficiently. The Beethoven Andante was much better, as the player seemed to be more in sympathy with the piece. The | Mendelssohn Rondo was good, but it is not profoundly impressive, and much of it is rather colourless. The one piece Mr. Koehler played really well was the Finale de la Walkurie. This his own arrangement for piano, I understand is an admirable and delightful piece, instinct with colour and great breadth and variety. He brought out all its beauty and gave to the full the continuous tone which characterised it. Ono part-an effect for violins-was delightful though all too short, and he did full justice to it. The rest was fair but showed the same tendency to apathy and even depression as the Huminel. Mr. Koehler is, however, a sound musician and a good pianist. The fire and temperament which he showed in the "Walkurie' would probably have been called forth more fully in a selection of somewhat more emphatic music than that of his programme.

div.p: Durant la mois de Février, les, Agrivages du Korfødan ont augmenté d'importance et, ila continueront probablement encore à être abondants durant le mois de Mars, surtout si le Gouvernement ne réquisitionne pas les chameaux de la région pour le transport de ses denrées. A Duem, les prix ont suivi une hausse ininterrompue jusqu'au 16 Février où ils atteignirent P.T. 78 1/2 le Cantar de 140 rotolis, mais, après cette date, les cours ont continuellement fléchi et il ne sont aujourd'hui que de P.T. 68 seulement. La cause de cette baisse réaide dans le fait que diyera n gociants se sont retiréz du marché tandis que d'autres limitent leurs gchats. Special arrangements will be made for part of the 7.30 am. Express train from Cairo to ran direct alongside.

This vessel is most luxuriously appointed, with accommodation (mostly in 2-berth cabins on deck, for 149 first class amid hips and 70 second class aft. Her public saloons are exceptionally spacious and attractive, and she is also fitted with 8 large cabins deluxe on the a spar deck, and an "Imperial" private suite on the promenade deck comprising sitting-room, Lounge, bedroom, 2 cabins, bath room, lavatory, etc., with private promenade deck above. Photograph of the verrel is on view at Thos. Cook & Son (Egypt), Ltd., and at Hamburg American Reise-Bureau, Cairo.

The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette," is published a midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhausteive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various maarket fluctuations, and the copies of the official of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for a yead abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Anjourd'hui à midi et demis) Les gromnes valours sont enooro dolatosdos, ot plutot on baisso. Três animés au contraire, le Comptoir qui reprend à 7 1/16 l'ancienne ot 6 13/16 la nouvelle, les Estates à 2 1/8, l'United à 1 5/32 l'action et 9 la fondateur, les Rite à 3 3/16; par contre, la Nile Land revient à 30 et la fondateur Comptoir à 7 7/8. L'Agricole fléchit à 8 7/8, et la National Bant à 26 7/16, cette dernière en perte de 3/8. En baisse encore la Delta Light à 11, la Bébéra à 39, la Privilégiée Bière d'Alexandrie à 222, la Cassa di Soonto à 281, 227 1/2 et 217, leg Nungovich à 28 3/4, la Land Bank à 8 11/16, l'Urbaine à 7 5/16 l'ancienne et 6 13/16 la nouvelle. La Salt and Soda reviont a 20 9, la Delta ! Land à 39/16, l'Aboukir à 40, l'Helouan à 3/4-25/32, et la Mécanique a 4 1/2 vendeurs. Plus ferme la Building Lands est demandée à 6 9/16. La Land Investment & Building fléchit i 13/10 l'action et 4 1/4 la fondateur. L'Arditi s'inscrit a 1 3/8-7/18 l'action et 26 la fondateur, la Levico à 1 11/32-3/8 l'action et 18 la fondateur. Tandis que la fondateur Union Foncière progresso à 25, l'action reste stationnaire à 5 15/16-6 La fondateur Allotment est inscrite à P.T. | 100, bien qu'il n'y ait aucun vendeur en bourse a P. T. 105. Impossible de préciser la tendance, surtout à l'approche de la liquidation, mais ceux qui se rejetteront sur les titres éprouvés feront acto de prudence L'annonce de la hausse du tuux d'escompte à Paris de 3 a 8 1/2 % produit ici une très mauvaise impression. On nous informe que les Estates ont vendu 22,000 pics de terrains près du Canal Mahmoudieh avec un bénéfice de 50 0/0.

div.p: Le Caire, Sendi 21 Mars 1907. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres reste à 5 1/8 pour cent. Aa Stock Excbange, le Consolidé anglais s'est maintenu à 85 1/2 et l'Unifiée à 101 8/4. La National Bapk, l'Agricolo et la D ira ont conservé leurs cours précédents. La Delta Light Beale a encore perda 1/8 à 10 7/8. A Parie, le Crédit Foncier Egyptieň a opcore rétrogradé de 1 frano à 737. La Banqee d'Athènes est demeurée inobangée à 181, Il devient de plus en plas difficile de définir l'état d'âme et, plas emocre, de relever la direc. tion da marohé égyptien. La tendance dana l'ensemble de la cote, des grosses valeurs notamment, continue à Utre lourde. Bien que la crise de New-York soit terminée, les inqoiétades n'ont pas absolument cessé et la spéon lation o'abstiept. Elle e mble attendre que les marchés d'Occident se soient remis ontièrement de la terrible secou980 de la semaine dernière et loi fournissent une première indica |tion onoodrageante Pour l'instant, l'approche de la liquidation aidant, l'offre prédomine la domande, et l'on réaotionne sur presq ne toute la ligne. On se trouvera, il est vrai, de la borte, devant une popition de fin de crois allégéa qui permettra un revirement sériquz 8088i 8t que la situation générale 88 sera tant soit peu Amõlioróo. Dans le compartiment de Barque, la Natiopál, très faible, & perda 5/16 1 26 5/8. L'Agricolo, plus lontende, s'est tassa, à 8 15/16. La Casea di Soonto a retrograde à 299-930. La Crédit Fopoier a encore reculé à 732-733. La Nile Land, poorsuivent sou mouvement Ascensionnel, a passé de 29 1/4 1/2 à 30 1/4-1/2. L'Allotment est revona à 3 1/16. Les Entrepri es Immobilières et Travanx, en trea bonde tepe, ont avancé à 9; leur parta o.Otoré à 128-129. L'action ancienne de l'Express Nilo a onoore donné lieu à an mouvement de spégulation qui l'a poussée à 12 1/2 pour olótarer à 11 1/4 !/2. Cette hs0968 a été certainement causée par ceux qai, an moyen de fortes ventes à déconvert, avaient commis l'impradence de ramener brafqmement, il y a quidze joure, le coura de 7 à 4 3/4. L'aotion Bouvelle a svadob 1 61/4; la part de fondateur a été négligée à 143. L'Epargne Immobilière a progressé à 2 11/163/4 ; ea part a termine ferme à 120. La Delta Light a faibli à 11-11 1/16 et les Joaissances Eaux da Caire à 263. D:08 le gronpa des valeurs hôtelière, les Nangovich ont été l'objet d'un bon moave ment qui leur a fait gagner ang livre à 28 5/8. Les Bgyptian oot flashi à 19 5/8 1 /16. Les National ont molli à 8 3/8 7/16. Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land s'est maintendo à 3 5/8 11/16. Les Abdy ont 6te demandés à 1 1/16 Los Ritz Hotels sont remontés à 8 1/8 3/16. Las parts de fondatear Egyptian Land lovestment and Boilding sont restées à 4 1/4. Rion de particulier à relever sur les autres titres. Par anita des fetos de Pâqae, il y agra cessation d'affaires, aox Boarees , da Caire et d'Alexandrie, le vendredi 29 Mare, le samedi 80 et le landi ler Avril. Noas détachons d'ano lettre de Londres, en date da 16 Mars courant, le paubage Baivant : "Cette semaine, la tendance générale de notre marebé a été faible, et il a été excessivement d fficile d'opérer. La plapart des nombreux ordres de vente dans le compartiment des valeurs égyptionnes provenaient da Caire ot d'A'exandrio ; mais ils sont restés pour la plnpart inexéo até, faute d'aobetears ioi aux prix demandés. | " L'argent poar la liquidation jrqi'a fil Mars a 646 obtenable aux m8 nes taux q i'a 1 l'qaidation précédente. Les positions ont été Aérieusement al égées par les liqaidations d cette dernière qoir zsine. "La deba le gar les titres des chemins de fer américaida a bouleversé presque tous le compartiments du Stock Exohange ; mais la baisse semble dev ir toacher à sa fin. D'un antre cô é, il est indéniable que les veutes for. cées effectuées ces jours-ci ont considérablement assaini la position de place. ". L'assembée générale ordinaire de la Cassa di Soonto et di Risparmio, tenue le 17 Mars ood rant, a établi comme suit le dividende de l'exercice 1906: P.B. 68 par action pour la actions des anciennes émission. Ua dividende intérimaire de P.E. 20 ayant été payé au m a d'août dernier gar les aotions des anoientes émissione, le so de lear revenant, soit P.B. 88 par aotior, ainsi que le dividende de P.E. 26.6 attribué aux act ons de l'émission 1908. seron payables, aax guicheta de la Banque, à Alxandrie et au Caire, à partir da 2, Mars 000rant. | L96 actionnaires de la Sooiété Agricole et Iadastrielle d'E.ypte sont convoq 1és en a8semblée générale ordinaire pour le jeudi 25 Avril 1907, à 4 h. p.m, au siège social au Caire. | A l'ordre da joar > rapport da conseil ; présentation de comptes et fixation do dividende pour l'exercice 1906 ; nomivation d'un aduinistrata ar et renouvellemeot partie du conseil d'après l'article 11 da- Statate. - Le dépo: des titres doit etre effectué avant le 10 Avril 1907.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS.
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them Bre fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, aid possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than any other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to On leaving Egypt is Sicily. Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio Rubattino Co's steamers, which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is m chto interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic renmates that are found all over the island, are an endless source of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in BC 212, when Archimedes was slain--his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pas au temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city he Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Erimiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria, every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay-Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento (you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where all other week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excurssions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade. In Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallum brosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from. Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cogwheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO, One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY.
GENOA (La Superba).
div.p: - The most I picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities, and a phenomenally equable temperature- warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble calumns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santa filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and-a-half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on as count of its thermal springs, change trains at Bergo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.
